item.description: Children's dexterity game themed on the popular Sesame Street character. Players compete to place plastic "feathers" into holes in the game board (depicting Elmo) and trying to not to "tickle" him, setting of a laughing alarm sound. Ages 3 - 5

This is a crossword-style game for children Ages 6 - 11. Players build words from letters rolled on dice. The dice are hollow, however, and are intended to contain small prizes rewarding players for having made words.

From the publisher: "Wonder Letters is the first crossword game where players create words and open WonderLetters to claim hidden prizes. Prizes are customizable - they can be tricks or treats, ranging from motivational stickers or jelly beans to jumping jacks! WonderLetters rounds out the fun with its unique triple-play rule and fast-paced, all-play piggyback round."

Wonder Checkers is a teaching implementation of Checkers. In addition to the regular checker board, the individual pieces are shaped like small cannisters, which open to reveal messages and prizes. The kit comes with stickers, customizable inserts, prize-tracking score sheets and game rules in quite a readable, logical sequence for new learners.

While the prizes supplied with the game are mere stickers and tokens, the designer suggests using jelly beans!

Wonder Checkers is part of a series which includes Wonder Chess, Wonder Go, and Wonder Letters, all of which are designed to teach standard rules and strategy of these classic abstract games by inserting intermediate rewards and tracking tools to motivate young learners.

On the reverse side of the board, an implementation of 3-d tic-tac-toe is also included.

Recommended for Ages 4 and up

Players answer questions related to the Bible to move up a rainbow gameboard. There are 2100 questions that cover seven categories (corresponding to the seven colors of the rainbow): Old Testament; History and Geography; Prophets and Miracles; Names; Letters, Numbers, and Sequence; New Testament; and Wisdom. The first player to successfully move up the rainbow and answer an additional question from a category chosen by the other players wins.

The questions are designed for children, Ages 6 and up.

name.value: This is your town: Parramatta game

item.description:
The object of the game is to move around the Australian city of Parramatta and acquire ten destinations cards by moving around the gameboard. The first player to do so, wins.

The contents of the game box reveal a mounted mapboard showing the cbd (central business district) of Parramatta divided into movement spaces, a pair of six-sided dice, 12 player tokens, a pack of money in different denominations, a pack of surprise cards and a pack of destination cards.

In preparation, each player is given a $100 cash scrip and a token. Tokens are placed in the locations indicated on the board, as are the shuffled surprise and destination cards. The first destination card is turned face up.

Each player takes a turn by rolling the two dice and moving round the board with the object of being first to reach the destination address. A player rolling doubles is allowed to go directly to the destination and claim the card. Each destination card claimed requires a payment of $50. Extra money may be acquired by moving to indicated spaces at a rate of ten times a dice roll (doubled if doubles are rolled). Spaces marked 'surprise' require a relevant card to be taken by a player and the text is acted upon. A player landing upon another's space may purchase a destination card for $25 from that player or take another turn.

The game ends when one player has collected ten destination cards.

Players are famous tank manufacturers of World War II, such as Krupp and Vickers, aiming to build the best tank of WWII.

Game comes with 108 "Magic: The Gathering"-sized cards.

This game is the third in the series from the same game designer, after Naval Competition and Prototype Competition.

Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Published in Game Journal #61, this is a multi-player card game in which players take part in the naval arms race in the run-up to World War I, aiming to build the best battleship and prepare for the upcoming conflict.

The game comes with 108 cards.

The designer also designed similar games subsequent to this: Tank Extravaganza and Prototype Competition.

Published in Game Journal #64, this is a card game with a very interesting theme. Players are World War II aircraft manufacturers trying to design the best fighter plane of WWII. Players can literally put together their dream plane, from jet-engined Zeros to Mustangs bristling with 50mm cannons.

The game comes with 117 cards.

This game is a spin-off from Tank Extravaganza that was published in Game Journal #61, also from the same game designer. The designer also subsequently designed a similar game called Naval Competition.

From the covers:

Sure...NASA is sending missions to Mars...
...but we're preparing to go...
Exploring the Depths of Uranus!

A mining game of strategy and resource management set at the very edge of the solar system.

Exploring the Depths of Uranus is a planning and resource strategy game where every decision you make will leave profound consequences. Trade, explore, or just shoot anything that moves...the choices are yours to make. Find priceless artifacts, valuable ores, and friendly (or possibly hostile) natives, but remember: this is Uranus, a harsh environment filled with toxic gases and unpleasant surprises.

This is the classic game of Monopoly with an America's National Parks theme. It uses images and names of 22 of America's National Parks, and has appropriately themed pewter tokens: Fishing Reel, Mountain Bike, Camera, Tent, Hiking Boot, and Canoe.
A simple math children's game. Players place cards on table and make equations. The aim is to get rid all of your cards.

Players impersonate squirrels who are looking for food: fungi, nuts, pine cones, rowan-berries. Cards are put in one pile and revealed one by one while forming another pile. When someone uncovers a squirrel then he/she must say which kind of food his animal eats. Player takes every card in reject pile with food that he has chosen and lays those cards next to others with this food. The player who collects the most number of cards wins the game.
Game contents 54 cards. 30 with palm trees, 15 with monkeys and 9 with bananas. Players collect cards with bananas.

Mare Bella is a children's game that takes place at the sea side. Players have to collect 5 hidden types of sea animals and avoid picking up rubbish such as tires and old boots that have been washed up by the tide. But if they do, they will have the opportunity to rid the beach of such litter, which brings its own reward.

For the younger player, the game has a simple environmental message; for the older player it has a gameplay in which a certain amount of skill and memory is involved.

Basic Rules:

Each player has a 'lotto' board, with space for 5 sea animals: a fish, starfish, crab, sea urchin (type thing) and an octopus. The aim is to be the first to collect all 5 of these, from amongst the square tiles that are laid out over the playing area. Players receive the 'beach bag' from which they draw a round token (same idea as dipping into the Scrabble bag that holds the letters). This token has on it a particular fish type or a particular colour on it. The player then chooses a square tile from the playing area whose upside corresponds in colour or fish type to the round token. He/she flips over the square tile to reveal its underside (which is likely to be different). If the underside is a fish that he/she hasn't collected yet, then the player adds it to his 'lotto' board. If the underside shows a pollution, he/she must collect the pollution. Once a player has three, then he/she may remove them from the game and get a 'free dip'.

Memorising the underside of certain tiles definitely helps, but is not essential, meaning that anyone can play from the age of 3 and up, although the game is certainly illustrated with kids in mind.

The game is soon to be available in the UK, costing around £18. See www.isimat.fr or email muellbauer@lycos.com for details

Tenka Fubu (War under the sky) is a multi-player game in which players take on the roles of the major samurai clans. The Takeda, Oda and Asai clans are battling for power from the 1560s to the 1570s. There's a political element, as alliances shift back-and-forth, as well as military action, as players' armies contest each other across the board.

Note: å¤©ä¸‹å¸ƒæ­¦ (Tenka Fubu) (under the sky - spread war) refers to the characters on Oda Nobunaga's new personal seal, which he inaugurated during this period.

Based on the TV contest Saber y Ganar (To know and To win). Ages 12 and up

3 competitors play, answering questions of general culture during diverse tests.

Content:

- 6 game pieces
- 936 questions cards
- 3 marking boards
- 1 rules book

From the publisher:

Quick, can you name a flavor of ice cream? Vanilla, chocolate, strawberry... you know tons of answers but can you be the last person to buzz in with a correct answer before the timer runs out? This game turns the concept of "sniping" a bid on eBay into the hottest new game around. With hundreds of questions and a random timer that changes every round, the fun will never stop with Snipe It! For 2 to 4 players Ages 8 and up

item.description:
From the publisher:

Race against time to unscramble Rock and Roll's greatest moments! Long Live Rock is the un-trivia game that challenges you to put all of the famous people, places, music, and events on the time line of Rock and Roll. Every second counts as you arrange significant Rock happenings in chronological order. Guess the correct year of a Rock happening and go on to win. A great party game for music lovers.

For 1 or more players or teams. Ages 14 and up

From the publisher:

"Find Puppy's Friends before the party ends!

Players take turns rolling the die and matching cards to "find" all the party guests. If you roll puppy's party, you cannot make a match and the party begins. The winner is the first to player to make 5 matches before the party ends! No reading skill required. Contents: 26 cards, die, game rules in English and French."

From the publisher:
"The fastest, highest, smallest, loudest, greatest and silliest trivia game ever! Each trivia question category - Entertainment, Food, Fun & Games, Mother Nature, Odds & Ends and People - contains 50 fascinating, far out and funny facts. Travel the game board and earn cards by answering the questions correctly. The first to collect 1 card from each category wins! The whole family can enjoy! Great for team play too. For 2-4 players or teams. Contents: game board, 4 game figures, 4 game stands, 300 trivia cards in 6 category boxes, game rules."

From the publisher: 
"The ultimate game to communicate, create, gyrate and (sometimes) frustrate! You have 60 seconds to give the best clues - can your team guess the word you're describing? Spin the spinner to determine how you give your clues. This charades, drawing and word game is fun for the entire family and comes with 250 words to guess. For 4 or more players. Contents: 250 word cards, spinner, timer, score sheet, pencils and game rules - all packed in clear bucket with lid."

From the publisher:
"Fifteen well-loved fairy tales are colorfully illustrated on game cards. Players travel the game board collecting these cards, memorizing them and placing them in their card holder, face-out so they cannot see the pictures. When you land on a "scroll" space, you must recite the cards you have collected! The first player to collect 7 fairytale cards, land on a "scroll" space and name all 7 cards correctly wins the game. No reading skills required.
Contents: game board, 4 game pawns, 4 stands to hold fairytale cards, 30 fairytale cards, game die, rules."

From the publisher: 
"Answer trivia questions about the wonderful world of horses - the various breeds, how they develop, where they live, how they're cared for, how they're ridden - each time you answer correctly you get to claim one of the 25 horses in the corral to your very own paddock. Collect the most and you win! Contents: 4 game boards (paddocks), 25 horse game figures, 25 game stands, 200 trivia cards, trivia card holder, games rules."

Contents:

 Board with spinner
 Six tokens
 Cardboard counters:
 24 gates
 18 single keys
 24 double keys
 6 triple keys
 
 Instruction booklet in five languages




Players begin with a supply of gates and keys and move clockwise on concentric paths connected at certain points via gateways. If someone has blocked a gateway by placing a gate across it, you need one or more keys to open it, then that gate becomes yours. You can gain more keys by moving away from the center or landing on another player. First player to reach the center wins.

When there are three or more players, two may negotiate a contract specifying how many gates will be placed during the current turn and where. A player involved in a contract receives a key for each gate he places as part of that contract.

Rupicola doesn't include trivia questions, but the spaces on the board are color-coded to allow players to incorporate trivia cards from Trivial Pursuit: Genus Edition (or any other such question-and-answer set) into the game. Playing time (average 10 minutes for two players up to 60 minutes for six) can be twice as long when playing with trivia.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
From the publisher:
"Bluff your way to victory! Players take turns laying matching animal cards face down. Since you can't see them, are you sure they match? Can you trick your opponents into believing you? If you can, you can get rid of your cards very quickly. But, don't get caught bluffing or you'll get skunked! Contents: 50 cards, game rules in English and French."

Contents:

 Deck of 42 playing cards
 5 reference cards listing the cards' ranks in order
 9 information cards about the animals in the game
 Instructions




From highest to lowest the cards rank Dolphin, Manatee, Alligator, Armadillo, Killer Whale, Sea Turtle, Numbers 12 down to 1, Flamingo, Eagle, Pelican, with two cards of each rank comprising the playing deck. Players are dealt a hand of seven cards and play out the tricks. On your turn, you must go higher if possible. If two like cards are played in the same trick, the second one beats the first. The winner is simply the player who has the highest card in the last trick.

The instructions say to devise your own scoring method if desired. They also include rules for a couple of variants in the rummy family.

name.value: Fargo North, Decoder Secret Word Game

item.description: A 1978 The Electric Company board game. Fargo North, Decoder Secret Word Game.

In this light card game, each player is given a mushroom, which he has to feed in order for it to grow. On the menu are fireflies, salad, trash, ...

Each mushroom has different characteristics and special powers which allow attacking other mushrooms in order to trigger indigestion...

name.value: Zip! The Fastest Dice Game in the Universe!

item.description: Zip your way to the winner's circle! Shake 'em, Roll 'em, Move 'em!!! The faster you roll 'em, the faster you win. Roll your dice, keep any aside and re-roll the rest. Be the first to roll the correct combination and move. Zip is the fastest dice game in the universe. Ages 8 and up

name.value: Conestoga: The Game of the Oregon Trail

item.description: Conestoga is a game in which players can simulate the feeling of the explorers who traveled west in covered wagons.

From the box: "The game of scramblin' eggs!"

Twelve life-size plastic eggs, eleven containing small foam 'yolks' and the other with a foam chicken are placed on a circular battery-powered vibrating plastic tray. In turn, players select and open one egg.

If the egg contains a yolk, the yolk is kept & the empty egg is replaced on the tray. If the egg is empty, the player must put one of their yolks in the egg & replace it on the tray. If the egg contains the foam chicken, the player is eliminated. All other players must yell CHICKEN OUT & the eliminated player must return the chicken to the egg & replace it on the tray.

The first player to collect the required number of yolks (varies according to the number of players) or the last remaining player is the winner.

Content:
1 board of two parts,
4 fishermen,
4 baskets,
20 chips (things that can be drawn out of the water)
4 magnets
1 die

Family trip to the lake: Everyone is eagerly hoping to draw the best fish out of the water. There are fish, of course, 
jewel bags, secret treasure chests and unusual implements.
Who got most of the points by fishing precious things wins the game.

name.value: Spider-Man and Friends Hide 'n Seek Card Game

item.description: This is a memory and matching game for preschool/early elementary age children with the theme of Spider-Man and his friends (including friendly looking Hulk and Wolverine). Memory/matching utilizes the characters, shapes, colors, and numbers. Different rule sets for basic and advanced versions, including the use of "clue" cards.

name.value: That's So Raven Star of the Show Trivia

item.description:
From the publisher:

Show what you know about the hit TV show "That's So Raven" by answering questions in these amusing categories: That's So Raven, Psychic Eye, Is That for Real' and Who Said What' The first player to reach the end of the game path is named the Star of the Show. Interactive gameplay encourages social interaction and lots of laughter.

name.value: That's So Raven "Tell It Like It Is" Game

item.description:
Social interaction/discussion style game based on the TV show.

From the publisher: "Join Raven, Chelsea, Eddie and Cory in this fun and "inquisitive" game. Who's your favorite teacher? Who's your crush? What's your favorite pizza topping? Get to know your friends by visiting their "corner" and answering questions. 2 to 4 players ages 7 and up.

Includes game mat, 32 friendship cards, 4 character tokens, 9 ch...ching tokens, psychic spinner and game rules.

name.value: Yetisburg: Titanic Battles in History, Vol. 1

item.description:
From the Paizo Publishing wesbite:
Four Score and Seven Yetis Ago…

On the bloody fields of Pennsylvania in 1863, two great armies collided to decide the fate of a nation. The South rose, and the North responded with fervent mettle.

As every schoolchild knows, at the forefront of the battle stood the mighty Yetis, white-furred giants imported from the wilds of Canada to shred the opposing front lines. From the rear, powerful mastodons hurled boulders into the fray. From even further to the rear, great generals engineered the destruction of the opposing forces—and quite often their own.

Yetisburg – This War’s Anything But Civil.

Yetisburg contains:

• Two decks of 55 cards each
• 60 tokens
• Initiative marker
• One rule booklet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Memory game in which players earn cards by feeding the third ball to each frog, while attempting to avoid overfeeding any frogs. The player with the most cards after three rounds wins.

name.value: A Batalha do Passo do Rosário

item.description:
Free print and play wargame in Strategos #3. It can be downloaded from the Riachuelo website. This small game a battle between Brazilian imperial troops against Argentinian/Orientales (former Uruguay's inhabitants), in Rio Grande do Sul (state of south of the Brazil).

Features a 8.5" x 11" map of mainly very uneven terrain, 50 counters, and concise rules, terrain and combat tables in Portuguese.

Victory Conditions are determined by accumulation of Victory Points for eliminating cavalry, leaders, and artillery scored at the end of 7 turns. 
A player is awarded a Tactical Victory if by the last turn, he has scored 7 more VPs than his opponent. He wins a Decisive Victory if by the last turn, he has scored 15 more VPs than his opponent. 
Any other result is a tie.

An educational trivia game for young and expecting parents. Contains more than 300 questions related to pregnancy and the care of infants.

Each player gets a babycare card. There are 6 different categories. The player start his/her turn with throwing the die and move the pawn in the direction the player wants. The player has to answer a quetion in the category he or she lands on. If the player answers the question correctly, he/she places a Right-chip on the babycare card. Otherwise he/she places a Wrong-chip on the babycare card.
When a player has collected 6 chips, the game ends. The player with the most Right-chips, wins the game.

name.value: Pokemon Diamond and Pearl On a Roll Game

item.description:
This is a dice game where players attempt to roll patterns of Pokémon with the dice before rolling a Poké Ball and losing their turn.

From the publisher: Chimchar, Turtwig and Piplup accompany players in this exciting new Pokémon game. Roll the dice and set aside any Pokémon character that will help you get the patterns you need on your card. Roll as many times as you want on every turn, but watch out -- if you roll the Poké Ball, your turn ends and you can't score in that round. First player to get all seven patterns wins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: This is a children's matching/counting game based on the theme of the popular children's show. Players spin numbers on a double spinner, count to/locate pieces and look for matches in order to win "CD" pieces. The first player to win three CD pieces.

Players follow spinner directions to try to advance along a board representing a marathon. The first runner across the finish line wins. Multiple-choice questions quiz kids on measurement tools, length, weight, temperature and capacity, in both customary and metric scales. The marathon theme promotes fitness. Includes 125 questions cards, racer pawns, spinner and guide.

From the publisher:

At the cow's and pig's home.
Who will help the farmer and his wife to feed the animals?
If the sun is shinning the animals want to pass the time in the meadow, but if it is raining they quickly return to their stables.
Three suggestions for playing, assigning, puzzling and observing closely.
A Game & Puzzle growing with the child.
For 1 player and an adult.

Content:
board with watch hands, 20 action cards, 4 pawns, 1 wooden die

At midnight the ghosts slip out of the key holes and take their turns walking the halls. At 1 o'clock the spook ends. Which ghost will reach a key hole? Whoever does remains visible for the next 300 years! The ghosts throw the die and move according to the roll of the die. The watch moves forward and can be moved back by throwing a 1 or 6.

Turn the disk, and change the position of the pictures! Are you able to find the pairs behind the doors? Find all five pairs one after another, and you will win the game.

This is a variant of Husker Du?, but this game requires a player to find all the matches in one turn.

Historical themed card game for 2 players depicting the Protestant break from the Catholic Church. One player is the Protestants, the other is the Catholics. Players use Faith cards to bid for control of different nations. There are separate Faith decks for each player and a shared deck of Nations. Some Faith cards have special powers that affect the Bidding. Some Faith cards have special Event powers that affect the game outside of the bidding. Faith cards have period titles such as Martin Luther, Edict of Nantes, and Council of Trent. A complete copy of the rules is available for free at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Reform.html

Content:
board, 8 wooden penguins, 5 dice

Each player tries to run through a water landscape with ice floes as fast as possible and to reach the finish fields first. 2 dice give the approximate direction. The last penguin in the round may set back other further in front sitting penguins by using the ice bear. Drifting ice can change the whole game. When a player reaches one of the three finish fields with his penguin, he wins the Penguin Cup.

name.value: N30: We Are Winning – The Battle of Seattle

item.description:
A game of the "Battle of Seattle" in 1999. Two players, 11x17" map, 168 counters. 13 pages of rules & 7 of notes. This is a complete redesign of N30 I and N30 II at a more detailed scale.

"N30 portrays the morning blockades of November 30th. Two players represent the opposing sides; one represents protesters; the other represents the police, with their incident commanders, Assistant Chief Ed Joiner and Captain Jim Pugel. The protesters aim to show that non-violent direct action can work, show that networked organizations can defeat hierarchical ones, and bring media attention to the issues. The police try to break the blockades and allow the conference to open as planned."

"Each turn represents 10 minutes. Each protester cluster represents 20-30 protesters, of whom 10-15 may be arrestables; each police hard or soft squad represents 10-15 police; each police mounted squad represents 6 police and each police chemical team represents 4 police (usually with 1 armored car). The police forces include most of the units of the Demonstration Management Team. They also include squads scrambled from the Convention Center venue (and/or other police units in the area)."

Bezzerwizzer Family Edition contains 3000 questions in 10 categories. It can be played by up to four individuals or up to four teams.

In each turn the teams are asked questions in four randomly chosen categories. The teams are allowed to order the categories, as the points received for a correct answer is increased for each category.

Each team also has three tokens available each turn: one "ZWAP" token that allows for the swapping of any two categories, and two "BEZZERWIZZER" tokens that allow the team to answer a question out-of-turn - when the team knows better than the one at turn.

The "Family" part of the game is the addition of hints for child players. To each question a set of three answers is given, from which the child's team can choose, making it easier for children to participate together with adults.

The questions in the game are very up-to-date, referring to events as recent as the year of publishing. The language of the game is Danish.

Game consists of all players being dealt hands of standard playing cards and upon their turn placing a counter on a board (which simply shows all the faces in a card deck twice over) square corresponding to a card in their hand. Game is won when 3 'convoys' (five counters of one color in a row in any direction) of the same color are formed on the board.

Content:
board, 12 butterflies in 4 colors, 40 sun beams, 1 cloud, 1 special die

After a long and cold night the butterfly must awake. The sun rises. When a sun beam reaches a sleeping butterfly, he awakes and flies to a flower. The player who waked up all three own butterflies wins the game.

Six steel balls roll down a vertical board to land in various scoring bins at the bottom. A wind-up mechanism releases them individually onto the topmost of a series of steps that you tilt manually. The longer you can control a ball's descent to land on more steps without rolling off into the gutters, the more points it scores. But don't spend too much time concentrating on one ball because the next one will drop at any second. As you become more proficient, you can shorten the time between balls from Beginner to Expert.

From the publisher: "Take the Olympic Trivia Challenge and play through the Olympic 5 Rings. Test your knowledge while competing with family and friends. Learn how the Olympic movement inspires everyone around the world in friendly competition. Feature categories include: Athletes, Countries, Events, Olympic History, and Rules and Records."

Set includes game board, question and answer cards, medal cards, die and 5 playing pieces. For 2 to 20 players. 
Purchase supports US Olympic team. Ages 12 and up

An Ice chest full of color matching and memory fun!

Open the cooler to color-matching chills and thrills! kids Try to match freezer Pop Cards to the Ice Cube Die after its dropped through the Ice Machine dice roller while building memory skills.

2 levels of play forAges 3 - 7 with no reading required.

Content:
German dictionary "Duden", board,36 cards, 6 pawns, 6 counting stones, 1 die, 1 sand watch

When the players reach certain fields after throwing the die and moving, they have to fulfill different games around words and characters.
The player who won the most points and reaches the top most step of the stairs will be "Duden-King"

The color matching game with the tumbling pup!

The die in this game is a large colorful puppy. You roll the puppy to see what color you move to. You can connect the paths to make the game as long or as short as you like. The paths are also double sided to provide 2 levels of play for both beginner and advanced players. Ages 3 - 7 with no reading required.

From the box and website description:

"Experience the adventure! Be the first player to collect photos from eight Grand Canyon destinations in this exciting game of strategy, luck, and adventure. Roll the dice to advance on the river and trails, racing your family and friends. Use your gear and test your fate as you learn more about the Grand Canyon as you play."

item.description:
Monopoly style game based on the University of Nebraska

Tokens include: Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, and Graduation Cap. Board Spaces include: Herbie Husker, Memorial Stadium, Love Library, and Nebraska Union

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
Monopoly like game based on Florida State University.

Tokens include: Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, and Graduation Cap. Board Spaces include: College Avenue, Lake Bradford, Seminole Marching Band, The Phyrst, Sweet Shop, Landis, and University Union.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
Monopoly-like game based on the Iowa State University.

Tokens include: Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, and Graduation Cap. Board Spaces include: Union Drive, Cy, Reiman Gardens, Memorial Union, and Hilton Coliseum.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
(from box back)

If you've ever read the newspaper or a magazine, listened to the radio or watched TV, you're sure to be a winner in Headline Deadline, the game where a little general knowledge goes a long way!

It's an outrageous game of strategy and insanity as headlines are read out loud and your teammates start yelling out related facts at a furious pace. But the seconds are flying by as you try to write down as many facts as your hand allows - all within a 30 second DEADLINE!

Oh, no! Time's up and the correct matches have to be tallied before you can move along the track, rolling and racing towards the finish. But was that your sweetheart's fact you forgot to write down? Geez! You'll never hear the end of it!!!

This game exists out of 2 books (an expansion of 2 other books came as well). You place the book in the electronic device "computer" and put in the code of the page you want to play. Now you get trivia questions about the subject on the page of the book. This game can be played with two as well as alone. The electronic device is there, just to see whether you gave the right answer and to remember your scores.

From front of the box:

The Real Bridge Game - Using Real Cards - Which You Play By Yourself

The Fun Way To Bid And Play Better

Learn And Improve You Game Guided By Experts

Included 50 Prepared Hands

For Beginners And Intermediate Players

The board has a hexagonal basic area on which 5 levels are put together to a pyramid.
The segments of the pyramid can be turned during the game.
It is important to bring 3 or 4 own pawns out of the game.
A pawn is taken out of the game when there is only one pawn on a level.

Contents:
1 board
60 pawns
1 die
Each player or each team tries to have the most money at the end.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: The game is set on a ranch that takes in abused and neglected animals. The players are volunteers who adopt an animal and try to herd animals to the foster pens while caring for all their needs. In the process, players have to make choices, either just do the work, or stop and help others with theirs, which earns enlightened point chips. The winner of the game has the most of those.

name.value: 54 Jones: Keeping up with the Joneses

item.description:
In 54 Jones the Baord Game, you play clones of sewer worker 54 Jones on a training day in the sewers of subterranean 12 Station City. However, 54 Jones unleashes a tidal wave of 'shunk' to try and drown the competition. The first clone to reach high ground wins the game.

To reach high ground, each junior Jones clone must race along the sewer network, battling his fellow clones, shirkers, Cynthia and the endless ever changing labyrinth of tunnels. Players get the chance to rotate, lock and change tiles throughout the game. Only the most calculating and devious clone will win.

The game is now available to buy from Rathbone Games and comes with boards, counters, dice and sewer denizens.

There is a place with no time or space, wandering on the eternity of an inexistent reality. The beginning of everything and the converge of nothing. Welcome a new era of fantasy, heroism and eternal battles. The Eprion era.

In a very distant world called Eprion, two races must face each other in a great battle. The game comes with two sets of cards and figures. The cards can be creatures or spells. Each creature card has an associated figure that can be played in the board. The board is composed by 6 modular boards which must be placed at the beginning of the game: forest, ice, desert, swamp, lake and plain. The position in which they are placed is very relevant, since the creatures abilities are affected by the kind of landscape they are standing in.
The object of the game is to be the first one in defeating the adversary’s leader, which is protected by 2 gemstones and his army.

Eprion is not just a game. It comes with a very well written book with the story of this world where you can learn about the story of almost every character of the game.

This game advertises itself as "the first computer based Tank game in the world". It is a board game 'controlled' by an electronic handset which serves as a randomizer for combat actions. According to the instructions, the computer "has counters, gates, oscillator clock, programming, read out and execute functions. The 'brain' is made of three miniature TTL logic chips containing over 300 transistors, diodes, and many other components giving a vast computing capacity with a wide range of probabilities for conflict purposes."

In essence, this is a straightforward hex-map based battle game for up to four players playing individually or as teams. It contains plastic miniatures and a rectangular game board with pre-marked battlefield features. There are no battle cards or other modifiers apart from the handset. The game depends entirely upon the handset to determine the amount of movement and the result of any attack. The handset therefore replaces dice, but serves much the same function. However, players have the freedom to select position, and direction of movement, and the miniatures are marked with values that determine their firing power, and this has a bearing on the result of combat actions (see below).

Each team deploys a regiment of 8 of tanks (slow moving, high fire power) and 4 armoured cars (fast moving, low fire power) in a pre-mapped fictive country on the game board (Kazaldis, Armania, Sarapan and Calderon) separated by marked national borders (which are red) and terrain features such as a river (with bridges), forests, mountains, and buildings. Each country also has a major city marked by a blue border. Inside the blue border several buildings are marked, into which tanks cannot move, meaning they must navigate the city to get to the enemy HQ or get out of their service/repair area and back into combat.

The objective is simple: to win by occupying the opponent or opponents' headquarters by moving a tank (or armoured car) into the HQ space (pre-marked on the board), or by destroying all enemy tanks.

Though the mechanic is therefore a fairly standard hex and counter skirmish, the computer in the handset ultimately drives the game.

The handset consists of six small red bulbs, two buttons and three switches. The lights appear over six icons indicating conditions of movement (the computer determines 'movement points' which may be spent according to terrain features - for example moving through a city costs one movement point per movement but armoured cars moving in open country may move two spaces per movement point), result of firing, repair status and range of attack.

The bulbs have three states - on, off, and flashing, each of which has a different meaning (see below). Of the three switches, one is a power switch. The other two switches determine the conditions of the 'roll' on any given player's turn. One indicates whether the player has opted to attack or retreat (the selection becomes a variable in the computer's calculation of the result), the other on whether the tank is moving or being repaired (tanks under repair cannot move or fire, but if the handset indicates that the service has been successful, the tank can move and fire in that turn).

The handset also has two buttons: one red, one black. The black button is pressed for between 2 and 5 seconds to command the computer to run a computation cycle that will determine movement and repair status (depending on the switches). It will also secretly determine a firing result that will be shown if and when the player presses the 'fire' button (firing is optional).

The red button is for firing. When a player wishes to fire, they press this button and the computer indicates the result of the firing action. If the bulb is fully lit, the result is a hit and the tank with the lower fire power is destroyed. In the case of equal firepower, the attacking tank is considered to have the advantage and destroys the defender. If the bulb flashes, the tank with the lower fire power is damaged and must be placed on a service space for repair. If the bulb stays dark, the attack has failed. According to the instructions "When the computer is programmed for Assault the 'firing result' probability is expressed as a 50% chance of a Hit, 25% chance of Damage and 25% chance of a Miss, while the chance of a 'Service Ready' is 25%. When the computer is programmed for Retreat the 'firing result' probability is expressed as a 25% chance of a Hit, 25% chance of Damage and 50% chance of a Miss, while the chance of 'service ready' is 25%."

Firing is further complicated by the game board and player actions though. A tank in open country can only fire at an enemy tank in a directly adjacent hex in front of or behind it, and it must turn to face in the direction it wishes to fire. Within city boundaries a tank may fire at an enemy in any hex in contact with the one it occupies, though it must again turn to face the target. Ranged firing (two spaces) is possible in open country, but is again a random result from the handset. A tank which is allowed a ranged attack by the handset may fire across lakes and rivers, but not mountains.

Assault Of The Ogroids is a computer moderated solo board game published in the May 1987 issue of Sinclair User magazine, a computer magazine for the 8-bit SInclair ZX Spectrum.

The player takes the part of Deerfoot, a scout sent to gain aid for his city which is being besieged by the evil Ogroids. The board is a rectangle 12 spaces by 15 spaces, and the player wins the game by traveling across the board within 30 hours.

Every square entered takes a toll of the available time and the player's stamina. There are five different types of terrain, and the random encounters include finding useful items, meeting unfriendly monsters, becoming lost or finding a quicker route to your eventual goal. You lose once 30 game hours have passed, or if you are killed by a monster or other kind of encounter.

The computer program is approximately 90 lines of BASIC. It randomises numbers for combat and for encounters met along the way, and also keeps a track of the gold and items held by the player.

Gary Chalk designed the game and also illustrated it in a style familiar from the "Lone Wolf" game books.

Di End is very simple abstract game for 2 players. It could be played everywhere, every time, and could be played with chess or draughts (8x8) set. You've got 8 pawns each, all in 1. (or 8.) row. You must capture maximum possible number of opponents pawns in your turn. To win, you must capture all of opponents pawns or to move all your pawns which still are on the board to the last row. Ties are rare, but possible. You must pay attention, because it's possible to lose more than 5 pawns in one move, even if it doesn't look like. Easy to learn, hard (or maybe impossible) to perfect.

Swashbuckled! is Fun-at-Home Games first game. Played with different colored sailing ships and on a beautiful large world map board, the game is set in the year 1806, at the peak of Napoleon's power. The game is played on three levels: the first level is rolling dice and moving one of six cargoes indicated on cargo cards from one port/continent to another, avoiding ever changing bad weather and war zones, lest you sink at sea.

The second level features pirates that every player gets a chance to be, by the pick of specially marked new cargo cards, once your voyage is complete. Pirates need not reveal themselves until they so desire. Poker face is critical to this game. Pirates can attack merchant ships by rolling additional dice. Knowing when to hold and when to attack are critical to success. However, there are also a few Lord Nelsons at sea - the game's police force - that can Neutralize pirates.

Finally, there is the most exciting third level; the Secret Treasure Islands. With every game there is at least one, truly secret treasure worth 50,000 pounds that makes the game a fun, fast, in your face adventure. Since the location of these treasures changes from game to game, no two games are ever the same and although the better strategists more often than not win this game, no one is ever really out of it. The emotional intensity of the game often increases into a climactic finish.

The Box and Board are beautifully designed, money comes in British pounds (paper), ships are wooden and painted with different colored sails, ship manifests are included to keep record of your payouts, and variously colored lighthouses mark where you start and where you end. Weighs 3.3 lbs.

The Quartetto is played on a common 8x8 checkerboard.

Each player has four checkers, each initially placed at the middle four board positions of the opposite rows.

Checkers are moved horizontally or vertically any number of unoccupied board positions. Game play alternates between the two players.

The goal of the game is to place all own checkers in board positions, which middle points are vertices of some rotated square (being non-parallel towards board edges). The smallest surrounding box of this constellation being parallel to edges of the board must be greater or equal 5x5 board positions.

Complete rules text in

 English
 German




Quartetto is closely related to and implements similar concepts of Adrian Schacker's Mondrago (1992) and John Scarne's Teeko (1945).




 
 Game

 Board Size

 Pawn moves like...

 Winning Condition: Pawns form a...

 
 
 Quartetto

 8x8

 Rook in Chess

 rotated square larger than defined minimum size

 
 
 Mondrago

 5x5

 King in Chess

 rotated and non rotated square (any size)

 
 
 Teeko

 5x5

 King in Chess

 straight line or non rotated square

item.description:
This is a light weight 'filler' strategy game where you explore dungeons, kill things, take their stuff, return to town, heal your party, gain some levels, then start all over again with an even harder dungeon.

It's basically the stereotypical fantasy RPG done up as a strategy game where you manage a party of characters rather than role play a single character.

Fantasy Adventurers is designed to be a light, simple and quick two-player game that can be played almost anywhere, but includes rules for solo play and three players.

In addition to the game rules you will need a sheet of paper, something to write with and a single d20.

The game is only available as a PDF download and includes these PDF files: Adventurers Guide, Game Play Guide, Dungeon Builders Guide, and Character Sheets.

An evolution of the game "Rapid 4", "Rapid 4 More" sees players try to get four marbles in a row by dropping them into holes at the top of a vertical tray much like in Connect Four. The drop, however, is filled with levers that shift as the marble drops through them; players must drop marbles to shift the levers so as to drop marbles into scoring or blocking positions on the slotted gameboard below.

"Rapid 4 More" utilizes two boards instead of one, and introduces an element of negotiation between players -- block a winning opponent, make a move of one's own, or forgo moving altogether in order to block another.

http://www.uncleskunkle.com/

Derivative of line and stacking games like Score Four, players alternate turns placing a wooden bead of their color onto a board consisting of 16 steel bars in a 4x4 grid. The object is to get 4 beads of your color in a row. Each bar can hold 4 beads to give a third dimension to the strategy. The added twist that separates this from Score Four is that the middle four bars can also rotate to switch positions to add more complexity to the game.

Similar to:

 Score Four - You of course don't have to spin the center four posts...

item.description: Children's game themed on insect knowledge. Players play one of four insects (butterfly, bee, dragonfly, or grasshopper) and navigate the gameboard (depicting a spiderweb) by answering trivia questions about insects. The first player to successfully make it through the web to return to his habitat is the winner.

Defenders of the Earth is an action and adventure game for adventurers of 9 years up.

One adventurers team made of the most famous comic heroes - The Phantom, Flash Gordon and Mandrake - to save the Earth supporting a titanic fight against Ming, the tyrannical monster lover of the intergalactic war, and his wicked schemes.

The game consists in the fight of superheroes against Ming, who is in Ice Station Earth, constructed under an arctic mountain, and to rescue the prisoners who are there.

Content:

- 1 board
- 42 cards
- 4 player pieces: 3 heroes (The Phantom, Flash Gordon and Mandrake) and the bad guy (Ming).
- 2 Dice
- 4 gamer pieces for the ice warriors
- 1 instructions

name.value: A Game of Cats and Mice, The Lost Diamond, and Gantlope

item.description: This is a turn-of-the-century board game published by the McLoughlin Brothers, and comprised of three distinct games: A Game of Cats and Mice, The Lost Diamond, and Gantlope. It has beautiful illustrations, and a double spinner component which seems to be made as an answer to negative stigma surrounding dice. The game folds up and double as a box for components.

From the publisher:
"Here is a crazy mixed-up matching memory game. Use the sneaker to step on a card - the suction-cup heel will pick it up! If the card you step on matches a card in your hand you get to keep the match. Players compete to collect the most, all the while trying to avoid the worst thing you can step in - dog poop! Contents: 21 Step-In cards, 28 Step-In squares, sneaker with built-in suction cup, game rules."

name.value: Otto Il Maialotto che fa il Botto
Otto Il Maialotto Che Fa Il Botto

item.description: Pop the Pig® is an international preschool classic that is adored by millions of children–it’s the #2 best-selling new kids game of the last five years. Kids spin the spinner, pop a hamburger into the pig’s mouth, then pump his head. The more they pump, the more his belly grows until . . . pop! Kids love the suspense as they watch his belly grow; the player who makes his belly burst loses the game. Redesigned in 2013 to make it easier for kids 4 and up to play, children can quickly reset this pig game with one pump of the pig’s head and experience consistent belly busting game-play each and every time. Pop the Pig provides hours of fun and is completely kid powered (no batteries needed). For added convenience, all pieces can be stored inside the pig. Kids won’t see a pop up pirate, but they will get to pop a pig. For ages 4 and up, 2-6 players. From the makers of Gooey Louie and Jumping Jack.

item.description:
Game simulates the historian routes of the salt transport around the year of 1500.

Object of the game is to collect the components for a historical "Säumer-Zug" (salt transporting caravan) with horses, riders, accompanying soldiers and/or mercenaries to encounter the dangers of the voyage.
In the meantime you have to mine salt and to acquire food for your caravan.
If you think the time is right you begin your dangerous way from the Bavarian Woods to the equally dark Bohemian Forests in order to reach the Czech capitol of Prag the first and to achieve the highest prices for your salt.

The game is of outstanding component quality.
A wooden box, where the lid acts as one of 6 wooden game boards, 3 different sorts of metal coins, real crystals, small salt cans and other heavy metal game pieces (horseshoes, pawns etc.)are a joy to behold.

The game is a project of the profession schools of the German and Czech border regions Waldkirchen and Susice.

It is manufactured by special order only, delivery time over 6 months, as nearly every game component is hand-made.

Educational aspect is served as a Czech-German dictionary comes with the game as well as a historical booklet describing salt-mining and transporting of the time being.

From the publisher:

Be the first beautiful Bratz girl to make a round on the red carpet, answer questions from reporters, agents, fans and photographers and fill up her necklace with stylish and chic charms. The first player to reach superstar celeb status by collecting eight funky charms wins the game.

Game includes: red carpet backdrop game board, 4 molded BRATZ girl game pieces, 32 charms (8 per girl), 4 charm necklaces, 120 game cards (photo, press, agent and fan), 12 charmed cards, 16 multiple-choice letter cards, 4 yes/no cards and die.

From the publisher:
"Be the first to reach the finish line by climbing rickety ladders and avoiding slippery slides!

A truly unique 3-dimensional version of the classic children’s game! Players move their marbles along the board based on the roll of the die. If their marble lands on a space with a slide, gear, ladder or other challenging obstacle, they must test their skill! Contents include: 3-D game board, 4 colored marbles, number die."

"A new exciting arithmetic fun game for all the family"

This very unusual multiplication game uses numbered tiles and a placement grid. The strategy is similar to Blokus... players use the tiles to match a multiplication fact BUT they must place each correct answer in a square touching another tile. The first player to empty his/her tile rack wins.

Includes board, four wooden racks, tiles, rules, and a vintage ad flier from the company.

(c)1962 Educational Fun Games P.O. Box 56 Winnetka, IL

name.value: Angleside School Adventure: A Measurement Game

item.description: Players explore geometry and measurement as they move around the game board (representing a round school) using a built-in compass. Game cards direct players to measure, compare and categorize angles. Players roll the die to move, draw a card if they land on a question space, and use the built-in compass to find the answer. The winner is the first player to make it to the bus stop.

In this geography-game, dates and facts about countries are compared.
Every turn, (up to) 6 cards are placed face up, each showing the flag of a country. Another card defines the deciding category - like population, gross national product etc.
One after another, players now put a marker on a single country, simultaneously guessing how the country will rank compared to the other 5. The more accurate you guess, the more victory points you get.

item.description: Players place numbered tiles on the table. If they recognize certain mathematical patterns in the tiles on the table, they can put tokens on them. The player who can get rid of his or her tokens first, wins the game.

It's fun with grins and frowns as the whole family gets into this nutty game. Match your face with your game cards for miles of smiles.

A children's game that has a player drawing a card with a funny expression on it. The player then has to match their expression with the one on the card (optionally using the provided mirror to make sure they have it right). The other players must look at the players face and try to find the expression on the game board.

item.description:
Strike! is a loosely based simulation of the British car industry of the 1970's and was published free in a 1981 edition of Games & Puzzles magazine.

Players are paired together and act as representatives of their respective car manufactures. Each of the pair takes on the role of managing director, the other as union leader of its' work force.

The role of the managing director is one of expanding sales and profits against competition from other managing directors in the rival car firms.

The role of the union leader is to secure fair deal for the workers and secure the highest possible share of the company profits against the resistance of the management.

Strike! asks you to do the impossible: combine with players holding diametrically opposite interests to achieve your objectives within the company while helping to sweep the competition from the market.

name.value: Hand-Off: The Card Football Board Game
Hand-Off: The Card Football Board Game – Florida Gators
Hand-Off: The Card Football Board Game – LSU Tigers

item.description:
Hand-Off combines the strategy and decision making of playing cards with the drama and tension of college football. You take control of the action – bust out a big run, throw a game-breaking long bomb, make the big open-field tackle, or pick off the pass and take it the other way for a touchdown.

Hand-Off is a new and improved version of CSE Games' original critically-acclaimed Card Football: Premiere Edition game.

For one to four players, Hand-Off takes about 45 minutes to play and features the following editions (with more to come):

- Florida Gators
- LSU Tigers

Hand-Off also features Team Cards highlighting some of the best teams of all-time.

Bragging rights are on the line as players battle through four fast-paced quarters of Hand-Off action.

Bunjee is a simple dice rolling game with some risk management. Each player is playing a figure jumping from a tree, trying to fall low enough to reach the goal but not too low to avoid crashing on the floor. On his turn, the player launch the dies, hecks the result and decides to satisfy himself with the result of the dices or roll some dices again to better his score. Of course, re-rolling the dices includes some risk. Mechanism is very close to the Can't Stop from Sid Sackson.

The aim of the game is to win all 60 chips. Before playing starts the chips are given a certain value. It is allow just to play for the own honor.

From the designer:

In fact, Hazar is some kind of "Las Vegas in your pocket", played in Bars and Cafes, by groups having fun with losing or winning money... There are 60 steel-chips. Up to 12 players (5 chips each) put their chips on numbers in different combinations. The stakes are high, because, in the end, there is only one player, who wins the 60 chips.

20TH and 21ST Century Skirmish Wargame Rules

These miniatures rules have the unique feature of, your side keeps going until you either fail at something, or the other side successfully interrupts your actions.

From the designer notes:
"The rules are designed to be used for World War Two, Korea, Vietnam and The Soviet-Afghan War. That does not mean that they can’t be used for other actions more current or further in the past. I know that some folks use them for World War One, The Spanish Civil War, The Falklands and current actions in Afghanistan and Iraq."

"I think that each player can handle a platoon to a Company. That might mean two platoons of infantry (about thirty to sixty infantry) and a platoon of Afv’s three to five strong. I really believe your table space will dictate how many toys you want to put on the table. A Company per side or less will probably run one to two hours to play."

item.description:
Quote from the publisher's web site:

The basic unit is the battalion, usually comprised of three stands of infantry or three vehicles. The basic command formation would be (depending on nation/year) a Brigade or Division. Each Brigade/Division has an attached commander, and each side has a CinC stand. Commanders have Leadership ratings which influence initiative and the pace of the game. The overall rating of a formation determines which Decision Die (Activation) it uses, which determines how many units may act, how many auto-rallies you get, etc.
Units are rated by morale, which is the key element of the game. A unit's morale determines which attack die you use, which morale die you use, and how many times it can recover from panicking.

Fire Combat: The attacker must make an opposed die roll to hit and damage its target. The attacker rolls a die based upon its morale grade, so a Militia unit roles a d6 while an Elite unit roles a d12 to hit. The defender rolls a Cover Die based upon covering terrain; open (d4), light cover (d6), type of tank (light, Med. Heavy) etc. The difference determines how many disorder markers the target takes, and can force a Panic Check.

Attached companies provide fire support, and special units are important in the game. A unit can have up to four attached companies that provide Fire Die bonuses, help recover Disorder markers, etc. Example, a Battalion with an attached HMG company (+2), Mortar Company (+1), AA Company and Medical Company would get a +3 on its Fire Die, force attacking aircraft to make a Morale Check to press a ground attack, and automatically remove one Disorder Marker per turn.

The rules are fairly comprehensive and cover all the basics of the period -- air superiority over the battlefield, ground attack, artillery, smoke, amphibious landings, fortifications, mines, engineers, supply, paratroopers, gliders, etc.

Also included is a set of rules on generating battles and battlefield terrain, basic army lists, equipment lists, and some sample battles and campaigns.

Expanded by:

 Panzer Korps Campaigns

Publisher blurb (Yoka Games English Edition):

Throughout the rich history of ancient China, the Three Kingdoms has always been a chaotic and awe-inspiring time period. Larger than life characters such as the fierce SHU general ZHANG Fei, the cunning WEI warlord CAO Cao, and the legendary SHU strategist ZHUGE Liang have inspired generations of people with their stories of valor, deceit, and strategy.

Legends of the Three Kingdoms replicate this historic age and allows players to assume the identities of these fabled heroes. Combining these heroes with role play, battle, deception, and other elements, we created a fun and exciting game that can be shared with many. We hope you will have as much fun playing as we had bringing this game to you.

Legends of the Three Kingdoms (a.k.a. San Guo Sha) is a card game based off the Chinese classical novel, Romance of the Three Kingdoms, and shares many rules with BANG!. The differences are as follows:
1. The Monarch (Sheriff) may get an additional skill related to their kingdom allegiance; players routinely have two powers.
2. Weapons may have their own additional powers.
3. A card to let a player borrow a weapon from another.
4. A card to cancel the effect of other cards.
5. Peach (Beer) may be played by any player when someone loses their last life; there is no exemption of using Peach when there are only 2 players left.
6. The game proceeds counter-clockwise.
7. Reincarnation*: The Dead may return to the game (start with 1 life) when he gets 3 or 4 cards from other players (a player may only give 1 card to the Dead within his round); the risen Dead are not counted to the winning condition.

*(removed from rules since 2010)

item.description:
Przekleta Kopalnia (The Cursed Mine) is an adventure game about dwarves exploring an old mine. The dwarf who finds the treasure and leaves the mine with it is declared the winner. To find the treasure the dwarves have to use several items like a shovel, a lantern etc. To make the task harder the mine is haunted by a dangerous ghost which can steal the treasure from the dwarves or even force them to start their search from the beginning.

The mechanics are: a modular board changed by the players during play, and various powers the different characters possess.

item.description:
Content:
board, 6 Indians, 1 wooden feather container, 18 feather, 1 color die

Carefully the small Indians slide from totem pole to totem pole in order to get the prettiest feather from the hiding place. But pay attention - another Indian may sneak a feather away from you. Who will catch the most feathers?
